title: Cholera Vaccine, Live Oral: Uses, Side Effects, Interactions, Pictures, Warnings & Dosing - WebMD
description: Find patient medical information for cholera vaccine, live oral on WebMD including its uses, side effects and safety, interactions, pictures, warnings and user ratings.
cleaned_text: Uses This [vaccine](https://www.webmd.com/children/vaccines/immunizations-vaccines-power-of-preparation) is used to prevent [cholera](https://www.webmd.com/a-to-z-guides/cholera-faq) infection caused by a certain bacteria (V. cholerae). People can get infected by eating food or drinking water that has been contaminated. This [vaccine](https://www.webmd.com/children/healthtool-childhood-immunizations-guide) is recommended for people who are traveling to areas where this infection is common. Cholera vaccine contains live bacteria that have been weakened. It works by causing the body to produce its own protection ( [antibodies](https://www.webmd.com/baby/antibody-testing)) against the bacteria. [Vaccines](https://www.webmd.com/children/vaccines/immunizations-vaccines-power-of-preparation) may not fully protect everyone who receives them. While traveling, you should still avoid contaminated food or water (such as by drinking only bottled or boiled water, eating only fully cooked food). Ask your [health care](https://www.webmd.com/health-insurance/rm-quiz-insurance-basics) professional for more details. How to use Cholera Vaccine, Live Suspension For Reconstitution Read all [vaccine](https://www.webmd.com/children/vaccines/immunizations-vaccines-power-of-preparation) information available from your [health care](https://www.webmd.com/health-insurance/rm-quiz-insurance-basics) professional before taking the [vaccine](https://www.webmd.com/children/healthtool-childhood-immunizations-guide). If you have any questions, ask your [health care](https://www.webmd.com/health-insurance/video/what-is-the-aca) professional. Take this vaccine by [mouth](https://www.webmd.com/oral-health/anatomy-of-the-mouth) as directed by the health care professional. You should get this vaccine at least 10 days before traveling to at-risk areas. Do not eat or drink 1 hour before and 1 hour after taking this vaccine. This vaccine should not be taken at the same time as a certain [medication](https://www.webmd.com/drugs/index-drugs.aspx) used to prevent [malaria](https://www.webmd.com/a-to-z-guides/malaria) ( [chloroquine](https://www.webmd.com/drugs/2/drug-11365/chloroquine/details)) or [antibiotics](https://www.webmd.com/cold-and-flu/rm-quiz-antibiotics-myths-facts) taken by [mouth](https://www.webmd.com/oral-health/ss/slideshow-mouth-problems) or given by injection. Ask the health care professional for more details. See also [Drug Interactions](https://www.webmd.com/a-to-z-guides/video/vd-0801-atsp-12) section. Side Effects [Diarrhea](https://www.webmd.com/digestive-disorders/digestive-diseases-diarrhea), tiredness, [headache](https://www.webmd.com/migraines-headaches/migraines-headaches-basics), [abdominal pain](https://www.webmd.com/pain-management/abdominal-pain-causes-treatments), [nausea](https://www.webmd.com/digestive-disorders/digestive-diseases-nausea-vomiting), [vomiting](https://www.webmd.com/digestive-disorders/digestive-diseases-nausea-vomiting), or loss of appetite may occur. If any of these effects last or get worse, tell your [health care](https://www.webmd.com/health-insurance/rm-quiz-insurance-basics) professional promptly. Remember that this [medication](https://www.webmd.com/drugs/index-drugs.aspx) has been prescribed because your [health care](https://www.webmd.com/health-insurance/video/what-is-the-aca) professional has judged that the benefit to you is greater than the risk of side effects. Many people using this medication do not have serious side effects. A very serious [allergic reaction](https://www.webmd.com/allergies/allergic-reaction-causes) to this drug is rare. However, get medical help right away if you notice any symptoms of a serious [allergic reaction](https://www.webmd.com/allergies/anaphylaxis-15/slideshow-allergy-triggers), including: [trouble breathing](https://www.webmd.com/lung/breathing-problems-causes-tests-treatments). This is not a complete list of possible side effects. If you notice other effects not listed above, contact your health care professional. Contact the health care professional for medical advice about side effects. The following numbers do not provide medical advice, but in the US you may report side effects to the [Vaccine](https://www.webmd.com/children/vaccines/immunizations-vaccines-power-of-preparation) Adverse Event Reporting System (VAERS) at 1-800-822-7967. In Canada, you may call the [Vaccine](https://www.webmd.com/children/healthtool-childhood-immunizations-guide) Safety Section at Public Health Agency of Canada at 1-866-844-0018. Precautions Before you take this [vaccine](https://www.webmd.com/children/vaccines/immunizations-vaccines-power-of-preparation), tell the [health care](https://www.webmd.com/health-insurance/rm-quiz-insurance-basics) professional if you are allergic to it; or if you have any other [allergies](https://www.webmd.com/allergies/allergy-relief-10/slideshow-allergy-myths-facts). This product may contain inactive ingredients, which can cause allergic reactions or other problems. Talk to your [health care](https://www.webmd.com/health-insurance/video/what-is-the-aca) professional for more details. Before taking this [vaccine](https://www.webmd.com/children/healthtool-childhood-immunizations-guide), tell your health care professional your medical history, especially of: [immune system disorders](https://www.webmd.com/a-to-z-guides/autoimmune-diseases) (such as due to [HIV](https://www.webmd.com/hiv-aids/understanding-aids-hiv-basics) infection, certain cancers such as [leukemia](https://www.webmd.com/cancer/lymphoma/understanding-leukemia-basics)/ [lymphoma](https://www.webmd.com/cancer/lymphoma/lymphoma-cancer), [cancer](https://www.webmd.com/cancer/health-check-cancer-risk/default.htm) or [radiation](https://www.webmd.com/cancer/what-to-expect-from-radiation-therapy) treatment). A weakened form of the bacteria may pass in your stools for at least 7 days after taking this vaccine. Rarely, an infection may occur in people who are in close contact with you. To prevent the spread of infection, always [wash your hands](https://www.webmd.com/cold-and-flu/cold-prevention-hand-washing) well after using the bathroom and before preparing/handling any food. Discuss the risks and benefits of this vaccine with your health care professional if you have family/household members with weakened immune systems (such as due to cancer). During pregnancy, this vaccine should be taken only when clearly needed. Discuss the risks and benefits with your health care professional. It is unknown if this vaccine passes into [breast](https://www.webmd.com/women/picture-of-the-breasts) milk. Consult your health care professional before breast-feeding. Interactions [Drug interactions](https://www.webmd.com/a-to-z-guides/video/vd-0801-atsp-12) may change how your [medications](https://www.webmd.com/drugs/index-drugs.aspx) work or increase your risk for serious side effects. This document does not contain all possible drug interactions. Keep a list of all the products you use (including prescription/nonprescription drugs and herbal products) and share it with your [health care](https://www.webmd.com/health-insurance/rm-quiz-insurance-basics) professional. Do not start, stop, or change the dosage of any medicines without your doctor's approval. Some products that may interact with this [vaccine](https://www.webmd.com/children/vaccines/immunizations-vaccines-power-of-preparation) are: drugs that [chemotherapy](https://www.webmd.com/cancer/chemotherapy-what-to-expect), corticosteroids treat [bacterial infections](https://www.webmd.com/a-to-z-guides/bacterial-and-viral-infections) ( [antibiotics](https://www.webmd.com/cold-and-flu/rm-quiz-antibiotics-myths-facts)) by [mouth](https://www.webmd.com/oral-health/anatomy-of-the-mouth) or injection when receiving this [vaccine](https://www.webmd.com/children/healthtool-childhood-immunizations-guide). If you are currently using an antibiotic by [mouth](https://www.webmd.com/oral-health/ss/slideshow-mouth-problems) or injection, do not take this vaccine until at least 14 days after stopping the antibiotic. Avoid taking a certain [medication](https://www.webmd.com/drugs/index-drugs.aspx) ( [chloroquine](https://www.webmd.com/drugs/2/drug-11365/chloroquine/details)) used to prevent [malaria](https://www.webmd.com/a-to-z-guides/malaria) when receiving this vaccine. Take this vaccine at least 10 days before you start treatment with [chloroquine](https://www.webmd.com/drugs/2/drug-8751/chloroquine+injection/details). Overdose Not applicable. Keep all regular medical and lab appointments. Not applicable. Store in the refrigerator away from light and moisture. This [vaccine](https://www.webmd.com/children/vaccines/immunizations-vaccines-power-of-preparation) may also be stored at room temperature for up to 5 days. Keep all [medications](https://www.webmd.com/drugs/index-drugs.aspx) away from children and pets. Do not flush medications down the toilet or pour them into a drain unless instructed to do so. Properly discard this product when it is expired or no longer needed. Consult your [pharmacist](https://www.webmd.com/a-to-z-guides/features/pharmacists-they-do-more-than-fill-prescriptions) or local waste disposal company.
